sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Positively no—I don't know one that I should not let fly away with the rest.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now, how can you fib, with such an unblushing face? This debate, Madam, [to Emily] will let you into Bella's secret—she has, at this moment, an image in her heart, that gives a flat contradiction to her tongue.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed!—you make your assertion with great effrontery—but now, to compliment your discernment, whose image do you think of?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha, Bella—listen with your greediest ears to catch the transporting sound—breathe not, ye softest Zephyrs! be silent, ye harmonious Spheres! while I articulate the name of—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [stopping her ears] Oh, I won't hear it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Belville!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, frightful!—don't attend to him—George's belief is always under the influence of his fancy.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: In this instance, if I may judge from your looks, he has not hinted at a fiction.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Indeed you are mistaken; his guess might have been as good, if you had named Prester John.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hum—I wish it may be so, for I have heard a story about a certain Lady on the Continent, whom a certain Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thinks handsomer than Bella Sydney—mortifying—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay more, to whom be devotes his hours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: His heart

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: On whom he doats.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Psha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Grows melancholy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nonsense!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, fights for her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Lives only at her feet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You are really very insupportable, Sir—do find some other subject to amuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! the Gudgeon has bit—See, Madam, a Coquette struggling with the consciousness of love,—are not those pouts, and angry blushes, proofs of Belville's happiness?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I cannot perceive these proofs—Mr. Belville, perhaps, is not in so enviable a state.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, you are a good Girl, and, I assure you, perfectly right—Lovers, thank our stars! are too plenty, for an absent one to give us much pain.—What, turn your arms on your associate, George!—I'll break the league, and discover all.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You dare not, you love mischief too well—it is as dear to you as the sighs of your Lover.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A-propos! where's Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: In the garden probably—sighing to the winds—and I wish you'd find him—and leave us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha! Perhaps they'll waft his sighs to Harriet—and she must not hear 'em yet—and so, Sir Charles—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, pray make me one of your party.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Madam, I entreat you—believe me, they will not thank you—I'll tell you the story.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I'll hear it from Miss Sydney.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, if you are determined—

div2.head: SCENE, the Garden.

sp.p: In vain do I endeavour to conceal it from myself—This spot has charms for me, that I can find in no other—here have I seen—perhaps for the last time, Sir Charles Seymour. My Cousin's presence was unlucky—I should have heard him—but it would have been a crime in him to have talked to me of love—an insult that I must have resented—and yet 'tis the only subject on which I could wish to have heard him. Bless me! he's here again—he haunts this place—but he does not observe me, and I'll conceal myself; for I feel I could not now behave with proper reserve.

Ha, not here then!—Sweet resemblance of her I love! come from thy hiding-place. [takes a picture from his bosom, and kisses it.] In her absence thou art the dearest object to my eyes. What a face is this!
sp.l: "'Tis beauty truly blest, whose red and white
"Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on."

div2.stage: Enter GEORGE. Catches his hand with the picture.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ho ho!—so the Picture's come home from the Painter's, is it, Sir—and the drapery quite to your mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: The artifice I used to obtain it, those who love can pardon.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And how many times a day dost thou break the decalogue in worshipping that Image?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Every hour that I live. I gaze on it till I think it looks, and speaks to me; it lies all night on my heart, and is the first object I address in the morning.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, complete your character, and turn Monk—'tis plain you're half a Papist.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Why condemn me to cells and penitence?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That you mayn't violate the laws of Nature, by pretending to a character for which she never designed you. Your bonds, instead of silken fetters, appear to be hempen cords. Come, confess, have not you been examining on which of these trees you would be most gracefully pendent?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: That gaieté de coeur, George, bears no mark of the tender passion; and, to be plain, I believe you know very little about it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You are confoundedly mistaken—we are both Lovers, but the difference between us lies thus: Cupid to me is a little familiar rogue, with an arch leer—and cheeks dimpled with continual smiles—To you—an aweful Deity, deck'd out in his whole regalia of darts, flames, and quivers, and so forth—I play with him—you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Spare yourself the trouble of so long an explanation—All you would say is, that you love with hope—I with despair.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Very concise, and most pathetically exprest—melancholy suits your features, Charles—'twere pity your Mistress should encourage you; it would deprive you of that something in your air which is so touching—Ha! ha! ha!—poor Seymour! Come, let us go in search of the girls, they are gone to the wood; who knows but you may find a nymph there, who'll have the kindness to put hanging and drowning out of your head?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.l: Oh, would sweet Celia meet me there,
With soften'd looks, and gentler air,
Transported, to the Wood I'd fly,
The happiest Swain beneath the sky;
Sighs and complaints I'd give the wind,
And IO's sing, were Celia kind.

div2.stage: [As he repeats the verses, George, laughing, scans them on his fingers.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Cupid is deaf, as well as blind.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Her picture in his bosom, and kiss it with such rapture too! Well—I am glad I am convinced—I am perfectly at ease. He loves them without hope, and George was mistaken in supposing him so near marriage—but he loves notwithstanding—her picture lies all night on his heart, and her idea is never absent from his mind—Well, be it so—I am perfectly at ease, and shall no longer find a difficulty in assuming an indifference that is become real—Oh, Seymour!

div2.head: SCENE, the Wood.

sp.p: Insolent wretch!—Nothing less than the conviction of my own senses could have induced me to believe so shocking an indecorum—I saw her myself look at him with eyes that were downright gloting—I saw him snatch her hand, and press it to his lips, with an ardour that is inconceivable—and when the creature pretended to blush, and made a reluctant effort to withdraw it—my Youth, so full of veneration and respect for me, refused to resign it—till the creature had given him a gracious smile of reconciliation—Heavens! they are coming this way—sure they do not perceive me—See there!—Nay, if you will come here.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I entreat you, Sir, not to persist in following me—You'll force me to appeal to Mr. Drummond for protection.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You need no protection, Madam, that you will not find in my respect—But you are barbarous to deprive me of conversing with you—'tis a felicity, I have so lately tasted, that 'tis no wonder I am greedy of it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: If you believe your attentions would not displease me in my proper character—I ought to be offended that you address them to a person, of whose name and family you are ignorant.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Can a name deprive you of that face, that air—or rob you of your mind—of what then am I ignorant?—'tis those I address with the most passionate vows of—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
I positively will not listen to you—However, if the acquaintance should place us on a footing, I'll then
converse with you—if on my own terms. [Lady D. listening—Aye, or on any terms.] I have no dislike to the charming freedom of the English manners—you shall be as gallant as you please; but I give you notice, the instant you become dangerous, I shall be grave.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How dangerous—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, the moment you grow of consequence enough to endanger my heart, I shall shut myself from you—but as long as you continue harmless, you may play.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is not to be borne—I will not be harmless—I declare open war against your heart, not in play, but downright earnest.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Nay, then, I must collect my forces to oppose you—my heart will stand a long siege, depend on it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If you'll promise it shall yield at last, a ten years siege will be richly rewarded.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, no; I make no promises—try your forces; if you should possess yourself of it in spite of me—I can only bewail its captivity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your permission to take the field is all I can at present hope; and thus on my knees, dear charming Creature—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: There's veneration and respect!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—I will be so generous to tell you, that whenever you kneel I shall fly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And I'll pursue—till my Atalanta confesses I have won the prize.

div2.stage: [As Geo. is following Emily, Lady D. comes out against him with an angry reproachful air, and passes him.]

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: So,—there's a look! what a blessed Motherin-law I shall have!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What!—not stay even to explain—to apologise—follow her before my face—oh, Monsters, Furies! yes, yes, she'll yield without the trouble of a ten years siege—she can scarcely hold out ten minutes—oh, ye shall both suffer for this—I will go this instant—I will do something.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
Hah, my good Lady, is it so? ha, ha, ha! I must see if I can't make myself useful here. A Lady, who like my mistress gives way to her most unbridled passions, is the only one worth being served by a girl of spirit and intrigue. I'll follow, and aid your Ladyship with my counsel before you
have time to cool— [going, returns.]—So—'tis needless, here she ebbs, like a stormy sea.

div2.stage: Enter Lady DINAH, not seeing SUSAN.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: A moment's reflection has convinced me I should be wrong—he must not suspect that I influence his Father against the minion—nor will I allow her the satisfaction of thinking she gives to me the pangs of jealousy—but I will not lose him—something must be done.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, I was witness to the whole affair—Oh, a base man! I could have trampled him under my feet.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Base, indeed! but 'tis on her my resentment chiefly falls—oh, Susan—revenge!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I am sure my heart achs for you, my Lady—there's nothing I would not do—Oh, she's an artful slut.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: She's as dangerous as artful—I must be rid of her, yet I know not how.—Oh France! for thy Bastile, for thy Lettres de Cachet!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: There are ways and means here, my Lady—Miss told a fine tale to get into the house, and I fancy I can tell as fine a tale to get her out of it, and I shou'd think it neither sin nor shame in the service of so good a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: If thou canst contrive any method—I care not what—any plan to rid me of her; command my fortune.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, dear my Lady, as to that—as to your fortune, my Lady, that's out of the question—but I know your Ladyship's generosity—I think I could send her packing,—perhaps before night.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Can you!—The instant she goes, I'll give you two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: She shall go, my Lady, if I have invention, or Jarvis a tongue.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Jarvis! Are you mad?—I wou'd not have him suspect that I am concerned in the affair, for the universe.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, dear my Lady—I vow I wou'd not mention your name to him—no, not for another two hundred pounds;—no, no, Miss shall be got rid of, without giving Jarvis, or any one, the least reason to suspect that your Ladyship is privy to the matter.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I am convinced she is an impostor, and I wonder Mr. Hargrave doesn't see it—but there will be more labour in rousing his stupid apprehension, than in explaining to an enthusiast the conceptions of a Bolingbroke.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I am more afraid of Mr. Drummond than him.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Aye—he will support that Girl's interest, in order to mortify me—

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: That doesn't signify, my Lady—I have a card as good as any he holds to play against him—your Ladyship must have seen that the old Justice has full as much weight with the 'Squire, as Mr. Drummond.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I observe that Mr. Hargrave is continually wavering between them—they influence his actions like two principal senses—Mr. Drummond is the friend of his understanding, the other of his humour.—But what is the card you mean to play?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I mean to play one of his senses against the other, my Lady, that's all—for I am mistaken if I can't govern the Justice, as much as his whole five put together.

sp.speaker: Lady. D.
sp.p: That is indeed a card—my hopes catch life at it—Susan, say to him what you will, promise what you will—I suppose you have the way to the old fool's heart, and know by what road to reach it—at all events the Girl must be got rid of; the method I leave to you.—There's the dinner bell—I must walk a little to recover my composure, and then, I suppose, I may have the honour of sitting for the young Lady's foil.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I am sure she can't have a better—ha, ha, ha!—Two hundred pounds! Oh the charms of jealousy and revenge—I might have served one of your good sort of orderly old women, 'till I had been grey—these two hundreds will quicken Mr. Jarvis a little—we shall see him more attentive, I fancy, than he has been, and then farewell to servitude—Hah, Jarvis!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.l: "So look'd the Goddess of the Paphian Isle,
"When Mars she saw, and conquer'd with that smile."
sp.p: My dear Goddess, I kiss your fingers—I have been hunting for you in every walk in the garden.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why—what did you want with me, Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, faith, I have the same kind of necessity for you, that a Beau has for a looking-glass—you admire me, and keep me in good humour with myself.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, if you want to be put in temper, I've got an excellent cordial. Now for your parts—now to prove yourself the clever fellow that you think you are.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: That you think, my dear, you mean—but what ex-

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Listen!—We have discovered that the young 'Squire thinks eighteen a prettier age than fifty—that he prefers natural roses to Warren's, and that gravity and wisdom are no match for the fire of two hazel eyes, assisted by the reasoning of smiles and dimples.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: And he's in the right on't—didn't I tell you this morning they reckon'd without their host?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Here has he been on his knees at the feet of the Damsel, and her Ladyship behind that bush, amusing herself with his transports—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—I warrant her, 'tis the only transports she'll ever see him in. George Hargrave marry our old Lady! no, no—I have a very good opinion of that young fellow; he's exactly what I should be, if I was heir to his Father's acres—just such a spirited, careless deportment—a certain prevailing assurance—upon my soul, Susan, you and I ought to have moved in a higher sphere.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Come, come, you must consider this affair in another light; 'twou'd be a shame, that because this Girl has a pretty face, and was found weeping by a compassionate old Gentleman—it wou'd be a shame, I say, that for these reasons, she shou'd marry into a great Family, and cheat the Sister of a Peer, of a Husband—Read the story this way, act with spirit, and our Lady will, on the day of our marriage, give us two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Humph!—on the day of our marriage—cannot you, Child, prevail on your Lady to give me the two hundred, without tacking that condition to it?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Pho, Sauce-box!—Well, but these two hundreds now—what will you do for 'em?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Do for 'em—Oh, any thing—the most extravagant thing in the world—run off with the girl—blow up the house—turn Turk—or marry you.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Well, but the business, Child, the business.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: The business is, that we must contrive to open some door for this Girl to walk out of the house.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But how—upon what ground—when, and where?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, if we could contrive the business, I have no doubt of the spirit and fire of your execution.—Do you remember the occupation which once gave employment to these talents of yours—I mean that of an itinerant Player?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p:
Oh, yes—I remember the barns that I have made
echo with the ravings of Orestes, and the stables in which I have sighed forth the woes of Romeo.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, but have you any recollection of a pretty Juliet—a tall elegant Girl—in short, do you not remember one of the strolling party exceedingly like the strange guest now in the house?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Hum!—Why, what devil sent thee to tempt me this morning?—so I am to sell my honour—my honesty—

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Pho, pho—honesty and honour are sentiments for people whose fortunes are made—let us once be independent, and we'll be as honourable and as honest as the best of 'em—so let's go in, and settle our plan.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Well—'tis the fate of great men to be in the hands of Women; and therefore, my sweet Abigail—I am yours.

div2.head: SCENE, an Apartment.

sp.speaker: BELLA.
sp.p: NAY, but hear him—hear him, Harriet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Can this be you, Bella, who this morning seem'd fearful that I should not treat him with sufficient scorn—now persuading me to allow a private interview to a Man who is professedly the lover of another?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How apprehensive you very delicate Ladies are! Why must you suppose he wants to talk to you about love—or on any topic, that his approaching marriage would make improper?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why—what can he have to say to me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Admit him, and he'll tell you—perhaps he wants to consult your taste about the trimmings of his wedding clothes—or to beg your choice in his ruffles—or—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pho!—this is downright ridicule.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Well then—you won't admit him? [seeming to go] I shall tell him you don't choose to see him, tho' he is going to
leave us directly—but I approve your caution, Harriet, you are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Going to leave us directly, Bella!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Immediately, my dear—I heard him order his chaise, and mutter something about insupportable—but I think you'll be exceedingly imprudent in receiving his visit, and advise you by all means to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Bella!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well then you will see him—I shall acquaint him with the success of my embassy—but remember scorn, Harriet, scorn.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now, what am I to expect? my heart beats strangely—but remember, foolish Girl, the picture of his Mistress is in his bosom.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: The request I ventured to make by Miss Sidney, Madam, must appear strange to you—the engagements which I—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Renders it an extraordinary request indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I fear'd you would think so, and conscious of those engagements, I shou'd not have presum'd to have made it—but as it's probably the last time I may ever see you—I seize it, to tell you that—I adore you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir Charles! I am astonished,—in my Father's house at least, I should have been secure from such an insult.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Forgive me, I intreat you. Nothing could have forced this declaration from me, but my despair.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The engagement you talk of, Sir, ought to have prevented these effects of your despair.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I acknowledge it—and they have kept me silent ever since I arrived—but when I thought of leaving you in a few moments, I sound the idea insupportable.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The picture you wear, Sir Charles—might console you surely.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Hah—I thought you were ignorant, Madam, of my possessing it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Without doubt you did, Sir Charles—but no, Sir—I am acquainted with your wearing that Picture—and wonder how you could presume—but I deserve the insult, for listening to you a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Oh, stay, Miss Hargrave, I intreat you,—I will give up the picture, since it so offends you—yet how can I part from it?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, keep it, Sir—keep it by all means—you mistake me entirely, Sir; I have no right to claim such a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: You have a right, Madam—here it is— [kissing and offering it] but do not rob me of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Rob you of it!—in short, Sir Charles, you redouble your rudeness every moment—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I did not think you would have so resented it—but I resign it to you, Madam—nay, you must take it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I take it, Sir! [Glances her eye on it, then takes it with an air of doubt]—My Picture!—astonishing!

div2.stage: Enter GEORGE and BELLA, both laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Your picture, Madam!!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Look at the simpletons—na, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What a fine attitude!—do it again, Sir Charles—ha, ha, ha!—Well, Harriet—how do you like Sir Charles's Mistress? Is she as handsome as George represented her?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hold, hold! 'tis time now to have mercy. My dear Harriet, allow me to present to you my most valued friend, as the Man whom I shou'd rejoice to see your Husband. To you, my Seymour, I present a Sister, whose heart has no engagements that I am acquainted with, to supersede your claim.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I am speechless with joy, and with amazement.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Forgive the embarrasment I have occasion'd you—you have suffer'd something; but your felicity will be heighten'd from the comparison. My dear Harriet, Seymour has always loved you—the picture which so offended you is a proof, you cannot doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: And that you were so offended, is supreme felicity—stupid wretch—not to perceive my bliss!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have taken a liberty with me that I cannot pardon.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay, but you shall pardon it—and as a proof, give him back your picture this minute.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Return it to me, Madam, I intreat you [kneeling] I will receive it as the most precious gift.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come, give the poor thing its bauble.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well, take it, Sir—since you had no share in this brilliant contrivance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Eternal blessings on that hand!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You, George, are never so happy, as in exercising your wit, at my expence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And you, Harriet, never so heartily forgave me in your Life, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Hold, George—I cannot bear Miss Hargrave's suffering in this manner; I will take on myself the transporting office of defending her—this hour, Madam, I shall for ever remember with gratitude, and will endeavour to deserve it, by a life devoted to your happiness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come, Harriet—I must take you away, that Sir Charles may bring down his raptures to the standard of common mortals—at present, I see his in the clouds.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis merciful to relieve me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Charming Miss Sydney—I'll never quarrel with your vivacity again.—But why have I been made to suffer thus?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Because you did not tell me why you wanted my Sister's picture—but I have taken a friendly vengeance; my plot has told you more of my Sister's heart in a few hours, than all your sighs and humility, wou'd have obtained in as many months.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: For which I thank you—and my present happiness receives a brighter glow from this illusion of misery—I'll fly and pour out my joy and gratitude, at the feet of my charming Harriet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, stay, stay—we may want your assistance. Here's your Father coming, George. Your repartee to Lady Dinah at dinner, spoilt her digestion—and she's been representing you—that's all.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I hope she represented her sneer too, which suffused with tears the loveliest eyes in the world. Could I do less than support her against the ill-humour of that antiquated pedant?—By Jupiter, I'll draw her in colours to my Father, that shall make him shrink from the fate he is preparing for himself.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, George, how's this?—Dy'e know what you've done?—you've affronted Lady Dinah.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I did not design to affront her, Sir—I only meant to convince her that she shou'd not insult the amiable young Lady, whom Mr. Drummond placed under your protection.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Don't tell me—amiable young Lady! How do you know what she is?—on the footing you are with Lady Dinah, let me tell you, if she had insulted an hundred young Ladies, you ought not to have seen it—at least, not resented it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir—I did not conceive that Lady Dinah shou'd have assumed in your house—at least till she becomes your Wife—a right to—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What's that you say, Sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, to confess the truth, I am astonish'd at your partiality for that Lady—she is the last woman in the world, whom I could wish to see in the place of my amiable Mother.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Your Mother!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I shou'd think it a breach of my duty, to see you plunge yourself into so irretrievable a fate, without acquainting you with my sentiments—if you saw her in the light I do, Sir—you would think on your wedding day with horror.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why—why—are you mad?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: If you wished to keep your engagements a secret, Sir—I am sorry I mention'd the affair, but—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh—'tis no secret, Sir, I assure you—every body talks of it—for my part, I shall be quite happy in paying my respects to my new Aunt—I have put a coral string in my tambour already, that I may finish it time enough for her first Boy to wear at its christening.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir—I perceive that you have all that backwardness in obeying me that I expected, and, in order to conceal it, are attempting to throw the affair into ridicule—but I tell you it will not do—I know what I am about, and my commands shall not be disputed.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Commands, Sir!—I am quite at a loss—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well then, to prevent further mistakes, I acquaint you, that I design Lady Dinah for your Wife, and not your Mother—and moreover, that the marriage shall take place in a very few days. [going.]—And, d'ye hear?—acquaint your pert Cousin, that the coral string will do for your first Boy.

div2.stage: [A long pause, staring at each other.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So, so, so! and is this the end of all the closetings?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What the devil!—it must be all a dream.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Wife!!—Lady Dinah my Wife!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! dear George, forgive me, but I must laugh, or I can't exist—ha, ha, ha! oh, my Cousin Dinah!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Pray, Bella, spare your mirth, and tell me what I am to do—for I am incapable of thinking.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Do! why run to Lady Dinah—fling yourself at her seet, tell her you had no idea of the bliss that was designed you—and that you'll make her the tenderest, fondest Husband in the world—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Oh, Cousin, for once forget your sprightliness—I cannot bear it—Seymour, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: My dear George, I pity you from my soul—but I know not what advice to give you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, then seriously I think—ha, ha, ha! but 'tis impossible to be serious—I am astonish'd you are not more struck with your Father's tender cares for you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Have you no mercy, Bella?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You have none upon yourself, or instead of standing here with that countenance si triste, you wou'd be with Mr. Drummond.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: He is, indeed, my only resource—I'll fly to him this instant, and if it fails me—I am the most miserable man on earth.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What can induce Mr. Hargrave to sacrifice such a fellow as George, to a Lady Dinah?—Preposterous!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Her rank and fortune—and I dread the lengths to which his obstinacy may carry him; he has no more respect for the divinity of Love, than for that of the Aegyptian Apis—Let us find Harriet, and tell her the strange story; she is not the only person, I fear, to whom it will be painful.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Is it possible that Lady Dinah, in the depth of her wisdom, can imagine such an union proper?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Be merciful—Love has forc'd Heroes to forget their valour, and Philosophers their systems—no wonder he shou'd make a Woman forget her wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Egad, ▪tis a service of danger.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Danger! sure you've no qualms?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: No, no, child—no qualms—the resolution with which I could go thro' an affair of this sort, would in another hemisphere make my fortune—but hang it, in these cold northern regions there's no room for a man of genius to strike a bold stroke—the fostering plains of Asia, sor such talents as mine!

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Now I think England's a very pretty soil.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, aye, if one could be sure of keeping clear of a dozen ill-bred fellows, who decide on the conduct of a man of spirit at the Old Bailey, then indeed we need not care; for an air of Ton, and a carriage, on whatever springs it moves, introduces one to the best circles—But let us consider our bottom—this girl was plac'd under the care of the old gentlewoman, by a person of credit.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Pho, pho, what! she brought a recommendation—don't we know how easily a character is to be had—spotless as silver, or as bright as gold! 'tis a wonder she did not afford a name too; I warrant she had sufficient reasons to conceal her own.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: It does look like it, and there's a mystery in the affair—Now, mysteries, as my Lady says, we have a right to explain as we please.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Aye, to be sure—and this is the explanation. She is an unprotected, artful girl, who having caught a taste for the life of a fine Lady, thinks the shortest way to gratify her longing, is by gaining the heart of some credulous fool, who'll make her his wife for the sake of her—Beauty.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: True—That with this view she told her story to Mr. Drummond, who—innocent soul—not seeing her drift, introduced her here, where she attempts to succeed, by playing off her artillery on the gunpowder constitution of George Hargrave, Esq; the younger.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Oh, delightful!—why, if I continue with my Lady, I shall be her mistress as long as she lives—and now I think on't, I believe that must be our plan—You and I can be married just the same, you know.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Oh, just the same, my dear, just the same; nothing shall prevent that— [aside] but my being able to coax you out of the Two Hundred.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Hark! here comes the Justice—slip away, and leave me to manage him—I know I can make him useful—You need not be jealous now.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Jealous! no, no; I have liv'd among the great too long, to be tormented with so vulgar a passion.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Hah, hah! have I caught you, my little Picksey? Come, no struggling—I will have a kiss, by Jingo.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Lud! you are the strangest Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: You are wondrous coy, methinks.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Coy—so I should—What have Gentlewomen without fortune, to recommend 'em else?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Aye—but that rosy, pouting mouth tells different tales, I warrant, to the fine Gentlemen in London. I have been thinking you'd make a pretty little Housekeeper—yes you would, Hussey—yes you would—will you come and live with me?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Sir—I should like it vastly; but I think you had better go to London with me—I assure you, my
Lady speaks very highly of your talents in the law—and she has great interest—so, as soon as she is Lady Dinah Hargrave—Your Worship is acquainted with that affair, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Yes, yes; my friend has told me of it—but under strict injunctions of secrecy.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Secrecy! aye, to be sure—but I dare say Mr. Drummond has been informed of it.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Oh, I know nothing of him—he's queer and close; one can never get him in at a bout—he's not staunch.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I believe he is not staunch to our match; and if that is prevented, we shall leave the country directly.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Why, what can prevent it, Sweety?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Perhaps Mr. Drummond's advice; for he can manage Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Ah—but my advice will go as far as his, I believe; and do you think I'll part with you—you little wicked rogue you?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Then if you find the match is likely to go off, you must use all your interest to bring it to bear; and then we sha'n't part, you little wicked rogue you.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: That I will—I'll plead for the wedding as vigorously, as if I had an hundred guineas with a brief.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Well—but d'ye mind me? I don't like the stranger this same 'Squire usher'd here.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Not like her! why, she's a devilish fine girl;—adad, the warm sparkling of her eyes catches one's heart, as if it was made of tinder.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Upon my word—a devilish fine Girl—the sparkling of her eyes!—

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Oh—I don't mean—that is—Oh, I would rather have one kind look of thine, sweet Mrs. Sukey—for t'other I dare not squint at.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Hah!—I believe you are a Coquet—but however, I have certain reasons to wish this beautiful Angel out of the house. I have observed looks that I don't like, between her and young Hargrave—and—you comprehend me—whatever interrupts the marriage, we are gone.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: I understand you—you may depend upon me—let me see—how shall we manage to get her out of Drummond's clutches?

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: That's your business—I say, that must be done, and you must do it.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: To be sure, Mrs. Susan—let me consider—

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: We must have no qualms, Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: We will have none—but what your smiles, sweet Sukey, can disperse—I must venture a little—the tender passions make one do any thing. Omnia vincit amor, say no more.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: She shall be sent packing.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Have I not given you the word of a Magistrate?—But come now, give me one kiss, you little dear, cruel, soft, sweet, charming, baggage.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Oh, fye—you won't ask for wages, before you've done your work.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Stop—don't run so fast—don't run so fast, Hussy—

div2.head: SCENE, an Apartment.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I wish I had known it before matters had been carried so far—on a subject of this nature no woman can be affronted with impunity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I▪ am careless of her resentment—I will never be her husband—nor husband to any woman, but her to whom I have given my vows.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Hah!—have you carried your affair so forward?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have made that enchanting Girl the offer of my heart and hand, and tho' her delicacy forbids her, while our families remain unknown to each other, to give the assent my heart aspires to—yet she allows me to catch hopes, that I would not forfeit to become master of the universe.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: There's a little of the ardor of youth in this—the ardor of youth, George—however, I will not blame you▪ for twenty years ago, I might have been tempted to enter the lists with you, myself.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I shou'd fear less to meet a Hector in the field—in such a cause the fury of Achilles would inspire me—and I would bear off my lovely prize from amidst the embattled phalanx.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Bravo—I like to see a man romantic in his love, and in his friendships—the virtues of him who is not an enthusiast in those noble passions, will never have strength to rise into fortitude, patriotism, and philanthropy—but here comes your Father, leave us.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: May the subject inspire you with resistless cloquence!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: So, Mr. Drummond—what, I guess your business.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I suppose you do, and I hope you are prepared to hear me with temper.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: You'll talk to no purpose, for I am fixed, and therefore the temper will signify nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Strange infatuation! why must George be sacrificed to your ambition?—surely, it may be gratified without tying him to your Lady Dinah.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: By marrying her yourself—which, till now, I supposed to have been your design—and that wou'd have been sufficiently preposterous.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What!—make me a second time the slave of hysterics, longings, and vapours!—no, no, I've got my neck out of the noose—catch it there again if you can—what, her Ladyship is not youthful enough for George, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: True—but a more forcible objection is the disproportion in their minds—it wou'd not be less reasonable to expect a new element to be produced between earth and fire, than that felicity shou'd be the result of such a marriage.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Psha, psha—what, do you suppose the whole world has the same idle notions about love and constancy, and stuff, that you have? D'ye think, if George was to become a widower at five and twenty, he'd whine all his life for the loss of his deary?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Not if his deary, as you call her, should be a Lady Dinah; and if you marry him with no other view than to procure him a happy widowhood, I admire the election you have made—but, if she shou'd be like my lost love—my sainted Harriet—my—oh! Hargrave—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Come, come, I am very sorry I have moved you so—I did not mean to affect you—come, give me your hand—'sbud, if a man has any thing to do with one of you fellows with your fine feelings, he must be as cautious as if he was carrying a candle in a gunpowder barrel.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: 'Tis over, my friend—but when I can hear my Harriet named, without giving my heart a fond regret for what I have lost—reproach me—for then, I shall deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well, well—it shall be your own way—but come, let me convince you that you are wrong in this business

—'sbud! I tell you it has been the study of my life to make George a great man—I brought Lady Dinah here with no
other design—and now, when I thought the matter was brought to bear—when Lady Dinah had consented—and my Son, as I supposed, eager for the wedding—why!—'tis all a flam!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: My good friend—the motives, from which you wou'd sacrifice your Son's happiness, appear to me so weak.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Weak!—why, I tell you, I have provided a wife for George, who will make him, perhaps, one of the first men in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: That is, she would make him a Court Dangler, an attendant on Ministers levees—one whose ambition is to be fostered with the cameleon food of smiles and nods, and who would receive a familiar squeeze with as much rapture as the plaudits of a nation—oh—shame—to transform an independent English Gentleman into such a being!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Well, to cut the argument short—the bargain is struck, and George shall marry Lady Dinah, or never have an acre of my land, that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: And he shall never possess a rood of mine, if he does.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There, I thought twou'd come to this: what a shame it is for a man to be so obstinate!—but hold—faith, if so, I may lose more than I get by the bargain—he'll stick to his word.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: I am very much surprized, Mr. Drummond—Sir—that I can't be left alone in the discharge of my magisterial duties, but must be continually thwarted by you.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: This interruption, Mr. Justice, is ill-timed, and rather out of rule—I cou'd wish you had chosen another opportunity.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: No opportunity like the present—no time like the present, Sir—you've cause, indeed, to be displeas'd with my not observing rules, when you are continually breaking the laws.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! let us hear—what hen-roost robbery have you to lay to my charge now?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, you may think to turn it off with a joke, if you please—but for all that, I can prove you to be a bad member of society, for you counteract the wise designs of our legislators, and obstruct the operations of justice—yes, Sir, you do.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Don't be so warm—what is this affair?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p:
Why, the poacher, whom we committed last night,
Mr. Drummond has released, and given money to his family—How can we expect a due observance of our laws, when rascals find encouragement for breaking them?—Shall Lords and Commons in their wisdom assemble in Parment, to make laws about hares and partridges, only to be laughed at? Oh, 'tis abominable!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Very true; and let me tell you, Mr. Drummond, it is very extraordinary that you will be continually—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Peace, ye men of justice—I have all the regard to the laws of my country, which it is the duty and interest of every member of society to possess—If the man had been a poacher, he shou'd not have been protected by me—the poor fellow found the hare in his garden, which she had considerably injured.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Ho, ho—what, the rascal justifies himself! an unqualified man gives reasons for destroying a hare!—Zounds, if a gang of ruffians shou'd burn my house, wou'd you expect me to hear their reasons?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Ah, there it works—Susan's my own [aside.]—there can be no reasons—if he had found her in his house, in his bed-chamber—in his bed, and offer'd to touch her—I'd prosecute him for poaching.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Oh, blush to avow such principles!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Look'ee, Mr. Drummond, though you govern George with your whimsical notions, you sha'n't me.—I foresee how it will be as soon as I'm gone—my fences will be cut down—my meadows turned into common—my corn-fields laid open—my woods at the mercy of every man who carries an axe—and, oh—this is noble, this is great!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Indeed, 'tis ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I'll take care that my property sha'n't fall a sacrifice to such whimsies—I'll tye it up, I warrant me—and so, Justice, come along.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: We were talking on a subject, Mr. Hargrave, of more importance, at present, than this; and, I beg you'll hear me farther.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p:
Enough has been said already, Mr. Drummond,—or if not, I'll give you one answer for all—I shall never think myself obliged to study the humour of a man, who thinks in such opposition to me; I have a humour of my own, which I am determined to gratify, in seeing George a great man—He shall marry Lady Dinah in two days; and all the fine reasoning in the world, you will see, has
less strength than my resolution—'Sbud, if I can't have the willing obedience of a Son, I'll enjoy the prerogatives of a Father—Come along, Justice.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: D'ye hear with what a fine firm tone he speaks?—This was only a political stroke, to restore the balance of power.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Why don't you follow, Sir? [Exit Justice.] My son shall be a great Man!—To such a vanity as this, how many have been sacrificed!—He shall be great—The happiness of love, the felicities that flow from a suitable union, his heart shall be a stranger to—but he shall convey my name, deck'd with titles, to posterity, though, to purchase these distinctions, he lives a wretch—This is the silent language of the heart, which we hold up to ourselves as the voice of Reason and Prudence.
Miss Morley!—Why this pensive air?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am a little distress'd, Sir—the delicacy of the motive which induced you to place me here, I am perfectly sensible of—yet—

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Yet—what, my dear Child?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Do not think me capricious, if I intreat you to take me back to your own house, till my uncle arrives—I cannot think of remaining here.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Then 'tis as I hoped [aside]—What can have disgusted you?—Come, be frank; consider me as a friend, to whom you may safely open your heart.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Your goodness, Sir, is excessive—Shall I confess—the Lady who will soon have most right here, treats me unkindly.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: That you can't wonder at—Be assured, I will effectually defend you from her insults—But do you not pity poor George, for the fate his father designs him?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Yes—I do pity him.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: If I dared, I would go still further—I would hope, that, as his happiness depends on you—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Let me not alarm you—I am acquainted with his passion, and wish to know that 'tis not displeasing to you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So circumstanced, Sir—what can I say?—He is destined to be the husband of another.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: It is enough—I bind myself to you from this moment, and promise to effect your happiness, if within the compass of my abilities or fortune. But, that I may know my task—favour me with the key to your Uncle's character.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: My Uncle possesses a heart, Sir, that would do him honour, if he would be guided by it—but unhappily he has conceived an opinion that his temper is too flexible—that he is too easily persuaded—and the consequence is—he'll never be persuaded at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I am sorry to hear that—a man who is obstinate from such a mistake, must be in the most incurable stage of the disorder. However, we'll attack this man of might—his flexibility shall be besieged, and if it won't capitulate, we'll undermine it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! my Uncle is in a state of mind ill prepared for yielding—He returned from Spain with eager pleasure to his native country; but the disgust he has conceiv'd for the alteration of manners during his absence, has given him an impatience that you will hardly be able to combat.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Take courage—let me now lead you back to your young companions—I am obliged to be absent a short time—but I'll watch over you, and, if possible, lead you to happiness.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Where the devil does my clerk stay with Burn! But I know I'm right—yes, yes, 'tis a clear case. By the statute Anno Primo Caroli Secundum—obtaining goods on false pretences, felony, with benefit—hum—with benefit.—Now obtaining entrance into houses, upon false pretences, must be worse—I have no doubt but it amounts to a burglary, and that I shall be authorized to commit—Ho! here they are! where is my clerk and Burn?

div2.stage: Enter Mr. HARGRAVE and Lady DINAH.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Aye, aye, here's a pretty business—bringing this Girl into my house now is the consequence of Mr. Drummond's fine seelings—he will never take my advice—but I'll shew him who is best qualified to sist into an affair of this sort—and yet I am a little puzzled—a stroller—

sp.speaker: Lady. D.
sp.p: It is, doubtless, a strange story, Mr. Hargrave—and I beg that you will yourself question my servant concerning it.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, what can she mean—what can her design be?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: To you I shou'd imagine her design must be very obvious, 'though Mr. Drummond's penetration was so easily eluded—By assuming the airs and manners of a person of rank, she doubtless expects to impose on the credulity of some young heir, and to procure—a jaunt to Scotland—that, Mr. Hargrave, I take to be her design.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Hoh, ho, is it so—now I understand your Ladyship—if your man can prove what he asserts, be assured, Madam, she shall not stay in my house another moment—I'll young heir the baggage.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: But consider, dear Mr. Hargrave, before you take any steps in this affair—that 'tis possible, we may have been deceived, for tho' my servant avows having been on the most intimate terms with her, he may be mistaken in her person, you know.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I shall inquire into that—she shall pick up no young heirs here, I warrant her—I shall see into that immediately.

div2.stage: Enter Justice, leading in JARVIS by the button.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Here's the young man—the witness—I have brought him up in order to his examination.—Here,—do you stand there.—In the first place,— [settling his wig] in the first place, how old are you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Fiddle de de—What signifies how old he is?

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Why, yes it does—for—if he is not of age—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Psha, psha—I'll examine him myself. How long is it since you left the strollers you were engaged with?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: It is about two years since I had the honour of being taken into my Lady's service,—and at that time I left the company.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And did you leave the young woman in the company at that time?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I did, Sir, and I have never seen her since till now.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am strangely puzzled—I don't know what to think—

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: It is indeed a difficult case—a very difficult case—I remember Burn in the chapter on Vagrants—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Prithee, be silent—at this time you are not likely to clear up matters at all.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: A Justice be silent!—a silent Justice!—a pretty thing indeed—are we not the very mouth of the law?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What does your Ladyship advise?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I advise!—I don't advise, Mr. Hargrave.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Why then, let the parties be confronted—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Aye—let the parties be confronted.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let us be confronted: if I once speak to her, she'll be too much dash'd to be able to deny the charge.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Did your honour call?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Go and tell my daughter, that I desire she'll bring her visitant here—the young Lady.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Two glasses of brandy, and tremble yet!—I wish I had swallow'd the third bumper.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Hargrave, it will be exceedingly improper, that I should be present at this interview, so I shall retire till the affair is settled.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: 'Sbud, my Lady, if you go, I'll go too—and the Justice may settle it as well as he can.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Nay, if you are for that—I shall be gone in a crack—I won't be left in the lurch—not I.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Bless me! I am surprised—only consider what an imputation may be thrown on my character.
So—now 'tis determin'd.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Robert inform'd us, Sir, that you requested our attendance.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Yes, Harriet—I did send Robert—'tis about an odd affair—I had rather—but I don't know—pray, Madam— [to Emily] be so kind to tell us if you know any thing of that person—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No, Sir, I believe not—I do not recollect—I may have seen him before.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Oh, Miss Jenny—you don't recollect—what, you have forgot your old companion William Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I do not remember indeed, that I was ever honour'd with such a companion—and the mistake you have made of my name, convinces me that I never was.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Psha, psha—this won't do now—you was always a good actress, but behind the scenes, you know, we used to come down from our stilts, and talk in our own proper persons—Why sure, you will not pretend to forget our adventures at Colchester—the affair of the Blue Domino at Warwick—nor the plot which you and Mrs. Varnish laid against the Manager at Beconsfield.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear Sir, nothing is so evident, as that the man has mistaken this Lady for another person—I—hope you'll permit us to go without hearing any more of his impertinence.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: If he is mistaken, no excuses will be sufficient—I don't know what to say—'tis a perplexing business—but I wish you wou'd be so kind to answer the man, Madam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Astonishment has kept me silent till now, Sir—and I must still be silent—for I have not yet been taught to make defences.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Dear Madam—why surely you have not forgot how often you have been my Juliet, and I your Alexander.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir,—if you dare utter another word to that Lady, I'll break every bone in your body—leave the room, rascal, this instant.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: You are too hot, George—he shall stay—and since things have gone so far, I'll sift the story to the bottom—If the young Gentlewoman is not what he represents her, she has nothing to fear—Speak boldly—where did you last see that Lady?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Aye, speak boldly—give her a few more circumstances, perhaps some of them may hit—People on occasions of this sort have generally short memories.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you cannot allow these horrid—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I do allow, Sir—and if you can't be silent, leave the room.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, or else you'll be committed for contempt of Court. Now, for your name, child, your name, and that of your family.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The name of my family, demanded on such an occasion, I think myself bound to conceal—my silence on that subject, hitherto arose from a point of delicacy—that motive is now greatly strengthened, and I refuse to discover a name—which my imprudent conduct has disgraced.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Ho, ho—pray let the Lady be treated with respect—a person of Consequence—stands upon Constitutional ground—a Patriot, I'll assure you—she refuses to answer Interrogatories.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot be any longer a silent witness of these insults—Your presence, Madam, supports that rascal, or he shou'd feel the immediate effect of my resentment.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your resentment will be unnecessary Sir, if he is not supported by truth—I shall take care that he is properly punish'd.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: A Gentleman in a coach-and-six enquires for your honour—his name is Morley.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hah—'tis my Uncle—I no longer dread his presence—now, Sir, you will be satisfied concerning my family.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Her Uncle—Heavens! Madam, what have we done!

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Done!—nothing—madness!

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: So, so—the niece of a man who keeps a coach and six!—we are got into a wrong box here—
she can be no Patriot, our Patriots don't ride in coaches and six.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—we have not done with you yet—you must now exhibit another part in this scene—what says your oracle Burn to such a fellow as this, Justice?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: Ay, you rascal—'tis now your turn—thou art a vilifier, a cheat, an impostor—'tis a downright conspiracy—The niece of a man who keeps a coach and six!—why, how dost think to escape? thou'lt cut a noble figure in the pillory, Mr. "Alexander the Great."

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir,—your honours—I humbly crave pardon for my mistake—I cou'd have sworn the Lady had been my old acquaintance, the likeness is so strong.—But I humbly ask pardon—my Lady!—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Expect no protection from me, I discharge you from my service from this moment.—The dilemma into which you have deceived me excites my warmest resentment.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Since Your Ladyship gives him up, he has no other protection—Who's there? [Enter Servants] Secure this fellow till I have leisure to inquire into the bottom of the affair—he is only the Agent, I am convinced.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but I am dumb—or we shall lose the reward.] I beseech your honour—'twas all a mistake.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Hah—are you suspicious, Sir!—I hope Susan has not put me in this fellow's power—I must be sure of that.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.p: 'Tis a conspiracy, that's certain—and will, I believe, come under Scan. Mag.
for 'tis a most scandalous Libel—but hold—'gad-so—let me see—it can be no libel; 'tis a false story—if it had been true—aye, then indeed—if it had been true
—but I'll go home and consult Burn, and you shall know what he says. Egad, it won't be amiss to get out of this Morley's way.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Surely she must have been privy to this scandalous plot—but 'tis no matter—my fate is at its crisis.—Mr. Morley's arrival fixes it.—At this moment my fortitude forsakes me, and I tremble to meet the Man, on whose caprice depends, the value of my existence.

div1.head: ACT V.
SCENE, an Apartment.

sp.speaker: MORLEY.
sp.p: A Pretty freak indeed!—a pretty freak, in return for the care and solicitude with which I have watch'd over you—I have broke with the Doctor for his share in this romantic affair.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am much concerned, Sir, that compassion to my situation should have led that worthy Man to take any step that you can think unpardonable—but when he found he cou'd not move my resolution, he thought it his duty to accommodate me with a retreat amongst persons of reputation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Retreat!—so, whilst I was condemning my sweet innocent Niece for stubbornness, wilfulness, and ingratitude—she was only gone to a retreat to sit under elms, listen to the cawing of rooks, and carve her melancholy story on the young bark—Oh, Emily, Emily! you ought to be made repent of this retreat, as you call it, as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I do repent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's that?—repent!—my dear Emily, I am rejoiced to hear you say so—I knew you was always a good Girl on the, whole—come, it sha'n't be a misfortune to you—I'll make Baldwin swear, before the ceremony, that he'll never reproach—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sir, I must not deceive you—my repentance does not concern Mr. Baldwin—he is—pardon me, Sir—my sentiments with regard to him, are, if possible, strengthen'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are they so, Mistress? then farewell to humourings—since your sentiments are so strong, your resolution cannot be weak—'twill enable you to bear this dreaded fate with heroism.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I am glad you can be so sportive with my unhappiness, Sir—where you jest with misery, you always design to lesson it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aye, that won't do—the easiness of my temper. Girl, has been my great misfortune. I never made a mistake in trade in my life, never, but have been persuaded, and listen'd to advice, till I have been half ruined
—but I'll be resolute now for your sake.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Surely, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aye, aye—I understand that speaking face—there is not a line in it, but calls me Monster—however, Madam, after your retreat, you can never expect to be the wife of another—so snap Baldwin while you can.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, allow me to live single, I have no wish for the married state—since he to whom my heart is devoted must be the husband of another.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No wish for the married state! ha, ha, ha!—why, 'tis the ultimate wish of every woman's heart—you all want Husbands, from your doll to your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: The person with whom one enters into so important an union shou'd be at least agreeable, or—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What an age this is!—Why, hussey, in the days of your great Grand-mother, a Girl on the point of marriage had never dared to look above her lover's beard—and would have been a wife a week before she cou'd have told the colour of her husband's eyes—But, now, a Girl of eighteen will stare her suitor confidently in the face, and, after five minutes conversation, give an account of every feature and peculiarity, from his brow to his buckle
—But pray, Madam, what is itin Baldwin now, that so particularly hits your fancy?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: His person is ungraceful, his manner assuming, and his mind effeminate.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Very true—and is not this the description of all the young men of the age?—but he has five thousand a year, that's not quite so common a circumstance. Come, take the pencil again, lay on coarser colours, or you won't convince me the picture's a bad one—considering the times.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Hah!—how different is Mr. Hargrave!—if I could urge his merit [aside]—You have heard my objections so often, Sir, that the repetition can have no weight—but, surely, I may urge my happiness.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By all means, it shall be consider'd, therefore—John, order my carriage up, we are going directly—tho' you don't deserve it—the very moment we reach Grosvenor-street, you shall be tied fast to Baldwin, who is now waiting there with the parson at his elbow—and we'll this moment step into the carriage, and away as briskly, as if Cupid was our coachman—come now, don't put on that melancholy air—'tis only to turn the tables—fancy that I hate Baldwin—that you are driving to Scotland, and I pursuing you—why the horses will move so slowly, you'll be ready to swear they don't gallop above three rood an hour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I entreat you, dear Sir, stay, at least, till to-morrow.—Oh, where is Mr. Drummond?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not a moment.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You have not yet seen Mr. Drummond, to whom I am so much oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have made enquiries, and have heard a very extraordinary character of Mr. Drummond; we can make him acknowledgments by letter—and you may send him gloves.—I know your design, you hope he will be able to talk me out of my resolution—and, perhaps, I may be a little afraid of it myself,—and so, to avoid that danger, we'll go directly.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: 'Tis so late, Sir,—and the night is dark.— [Aside] Yet why should I wish to stay here?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No more trifling—conduct me to the family, that we may take leave. If you complain of this as an act of tyranny—be comforted, Child, 'tis the last you'll experience from me—my authority will expire with the night, and tomorrow morning, I shall be my dear Niece Baldwin's most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What, refuse me your assistance in such an hour—talk to me of prudence in a moment when I must be mad, if I am human! yes, be prudent, Sir, be prudent,—the man who can be discreet when his friend's happiness is at stake, may gain the approbation of his own heart, but mine renounces him—Where can Mr. Drummond be?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: I am at your command in every thing—I ask you only to reflect.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes, I do reflect, that in a few hours she will be irrecoverably another's—lost to me for ever—unfeeling brute! to sacrifice such a Woman to a man whom she despises!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What then is your resolution?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: There is but one way—she hangs on the point of a precipice, from which, if I do not snatch her in an instant, nothing can retrieve her.—We will follow the carriage on horseback; let your chaise attend us with our servants—I'll force her from this tyrant Uncle, carry her instantly to Dover, and in a few hours, breathe out my soul at her feet—in sweet security in France.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Considering your plan is an impromptu, I admire its consistency—but, my dear George, have you weighed all its consequences?—your Father—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Will perhaps disinherit me—be it so—I have six hundred a year independent of his will—and six hundred a year in France with Emily Morly—kingdoms! empires! paradise!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: But are you certain she will partake it with you?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No—but supposing the worst—I shall, at least, have had the happiness to preserve her from a fate she dreads—for the rest I will trust to time and my ardent passion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Pity the days of chivalry are over, or what applause might'st thou not expect—advent'rous Knight!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come, we have not a moment to lose—let us get our people ready to follow, the instant the carriage sets out.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: But, George—George—I'll not accompany you a step, after the Lady's in your protection—for if your Father shou'd surmise that I have any hand in the enlevement, I can hope for no success, when I ask him for my charming Harriet.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Agreed—let me have your chaise, and leave me to my fortune—I will not endanger your happiness—this key will let you in at the garden-door—you may give fifty reasons for your short absence.—Now, Cupid, Venus, Jove and Juno, leap into your chariots, and descend to our assistance.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: She's gone, and my alarms are at an end—'tis plain I had never the least foundation for my fears—what pass'd in the garden was mere gallantry, and the effects of her art; he suffered her Uncle to carry her off with an indifference that transports me. How weak have I been, to allow my credulity to be imposed on by their suggestions, and my temper ruffled at a time when 'twas of so much importance to me to have been serene!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, she's gone—the delightful obstinacy of the old Uncle—It is well Mr. Drummond was not here—I was afraid—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your joy wears a very familiar aspect—I know she's gone.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I beg pardon, my Lady—I thought I might congratulate your Ladyship on her being carried off—I was terribly afraid—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Yes, you have had most extraordinary fears on the occasion. You ought to have known, that the man whom I had receiv'd as my Lover, could never have felt any thing like a serious passion for such a girl as that.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: So, so, so! how soon our spirits are got up! [aside.] I am sure, my Lady, 'twas not I who occasioned the interview in the garden to-day, that so enraged you, and confirmed your fears—you was ready enough then to believe all that was said against her.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: How dare you reproach me with the errors which you led me into?—'twas your fears I was govern'd by, and not my own; and your ridiculous plot was as absurd as your fears.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: As to the plot, my Lady, I am sure 'twas a good one, and would have sent her packing, if the Uncle hadn't come—'twasn't our fault he came—We have had the same trouble, and—service is no inheritance, and I hope your Ladyship will consider—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: How dare you think of a reward for such conduct?—If you obtain my pardon, you ought to be highly gratified—leave me, Insolent, this moment.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: Ha!—and dare you use me in this manner?—I am glad you have betrayed yourself in time, when I can take a severe revenge?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I have gone too far—Now must I court my servant, to forget the resentment which her impertinence occasioned—Well, 'tis but for a short time—the marriage over, and I have done with her—

I must retire to my apartment, to recover my composure: perhaps he'll visit me there—but not to talk of veneration and respect again—Oh! I'll torment him for that. Nothing gives a Woman so fine an opportunity of plaguing her Lover, as an affectation off jealousy: if she feels it, she's his Slave; but, whilst she affects it—his Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How very unfortunate, that Mr. Drummond is absent!—he would have opposed the reasoning of Lady Dinah; and prevented their departure—Sure, never any thing was so cruel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh, there's no bearing it—Your Father is quite a manageable being, compared to this odd, provoking mortal, whose imagined flexibility baffles art, reason, and every thing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Never shall I forget the look, wild, yet composed—agonized tho' calm, which she gave me, as her Uncle led her out. Her Lover must possess strange sentiments, to resolve to marry her, in spite of her aversion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sentiments! my dear—why he's a modern fine Gentleman; there is nothing he's so much afraid of as a fond Wife—If I was Miss Morley, I'd affect a most formidable fondness, and ten to one but she'd get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I wonder where Sir Charles is—he pass'd me in the hall, and said in a hasty manner, he must tear himself front me for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
I wonder rather where your Brother is—but the heart of a woman in love, is as unnatural as the ostrich's; it
is no longer alive to any sentiment but one, and the tenderest connexions are absorbed in its passion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I hope it is not in your own heart, you find this picture of love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh—here's one of our truants, but where's the other?—poor George, I suppose, is binding his brow with willows.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: That's not George's style in love—he has too much spirit to cross his arms, and talk to his shadow, when he may employ his hours to more advantage at the feet of a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Where is my Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: On the road to France.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: France!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: Unless Mr. Morley has as much valour as obstinacy—for George has pursued him, and, by this time, I dare swear has gained possession of his Niece.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! how I doat on his Knight-errantry!—commend me to a lover, who, instead of patiently submitting to the circumstances that separate him from the object of his passion,—boldly takes the reins of Fortune in his own hands, and governs the accidents which he can't avoid.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How can you praise such a daring conduct? I tremble for the consequences!

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: What consequences, Madam, can he dread, who snatches the woman he loves from the arms of the man she hates?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Master, Sir, is returned—the Lady fainted in the chaise, and he has carried her to Mr. Drummond's.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: The devil!—is he at home?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, Sir—and Mr. Morley is come back too—he drove thro' the gates this minute.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay, then George will lose her at last—he was a fool for not pursuing his route.

sp.speaker: Sir Ch.
sp.p: He has no chance now, but thro' Mr. Drummond; and what can he hope? Mr. Drummond has only reason on his side, and the passions of three to combat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, here he comes—and Mr. Hargrave, as loud as his huntsman.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Let us fly to the parlour, and then we can send intelligence of what passes to George.

div1.stage: Enter Mr. MORLEY and Mr. HARGRAVE.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis fact—matter of fact, upon my honour—Your Son was the person who took her out of the coach.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Sir, it is impossible!—ha, ha, ha!—my Son!—why, he's under engagements that wou'd make it madness.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you may depend upon it, tho fit is on him now, for he clapt Emily into a chaise, whilst an impudent puppy fasten'd on me—egad! twenty years ago I'd have given him sauce to his Cornish hug—I could not discern his face—but t'other I'll swear to.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: George! look for George there! I'll convince you, Sir, instantly—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Where's George?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, my Brother is at Mr. Drummond's.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There! I knew it could not be him, though you would not be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: What a plague! you can't persuade me out of my senses—Your Son, I aver, took her out of the coach—with her own consent, no doubt, and on an honourable design, without doubt—Sir, I give you joy of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: If it is on an honourable design, they may live on their honour, or starve with it—not a single sous shall they have of me—but I won't yet believe my George cou'd be such a fool.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Fool! Sir—The man who loves Emily gives no such proof of folly neither—but she shall be punished for hers—'twas a concerted affair, I see it plainly, all agreed upon—but she shall repent.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Your resentment, Sir, is extraordinary—I must tell you that my Son's ancestry, or the estate to which he is heir—if he has not forfeited by his disobedience, are not objects for the contempt of any man.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir,—but they are objects to which I shall never be reconciled—What! have I been toiling these thirty years in Spain, to make my Niece a match for any man in England—to have her fortune settled by an adventure in a post-chaise, an evening's frolick for a young spark, who had nothing to do but push the old fellow into a corner, and whisk off with the girl? Sir, if there was not another man in the kingdom, your Son shou'd not have my consent to marry Emily.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: And if there was not another woman in England, I'd suffer the name of Hargrave to be annihilated, rather than he should be husband to your Niece.

div1.stage: [Hargrave and Morley walk about the Stage disordered.]

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Gone!—her Uncle arrived, and the amiable girl gone—What infatuation, Mr. Hargrave, cou'd render you so blind to the happiness that awaited your family?—I'll follow this obdurate man—where's George?—look for George there—he shall hear reason.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: There, Sir—that's the person to whom you must address your complaints.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Unfortunate!—I have made discoveries, that must have shaken even your prejudices— [to Mr. Hargrave]—but this Uncle!—surely, my dear Harriet, you might have prevailed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, this gentleman is Mr. Morley—Mr. Drummond, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Hah! I beg pardon, Sir, I am rejoiced to see you; I understood you were gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: I was gone, Sir; but I was robb'd of my Niece on the road—she was taken out of my coach, and carried off—which forced me to return.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Carried off!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, carried off by George, whom you have trained to such a knowledge of his duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Stopt on the King's highway, Sir, by the fiery youth, and my Niece dragg'd from my side.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What's this right too?—By heaven, it is not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: At your house, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: What a country am I fallen into! can a person of your age and character approve of so rash and daring—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Let George do what he will—he's sure of his approbation.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: Gentlemen—if you are sure Miss Morley is at my house, I am patience itself—she is too rich a prize to be gained without some warfare.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Sir, I am resolved to—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Hargrave! so, Sir!—what, your Son—this new insult deprives me of utterance—but your Son—what is the reason of this complicated outrage?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: My dear Lady Dinah, I am as much enraged as you can be—but he shall fulfill his engagements—depend on it, he shall.

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Engagements!—what the young Gentleman was engaged too!—a very fine youth! upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Your honour is concern'd, Sir—and if I was sure he was drawn in by the girl's art, and that he was convinced of the impropriety—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: Drawn in by the girl's art!—whatever cause I may have to be offended with my Niece's conduct, Madam, no person shall speak of her with contempt in my presence—I presume, this gentleman's son was engaged to your daughter, but that's not a sufficient reason for—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Daughter! impertinent!—No, Sir, 'twas to me that he was engaged—and, but for the arts of your Niece—

sp.speaker: Mr. M.
sp.p: To you!—A matrimonial negociation between that young Fellow and you!—Nay then, 'fore George, I don't wonder at your ill temper—A disappointment in love at your time of life must be the devil.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Mr. Hargrave, do you suffer me to be thus insulted?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Why, my Lady, we must bear something from this Gentleman—the mistake we made about his Niece, was a very ugly business.

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I entreat you, Madam, to retire from a Family, to whom, if you suffer me to explain myself—

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: What new insolence is this?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I would spare you, my Lady, but you will not spare yourself—Blush then, whilst I accuse you of entering into a base league with your Servants, to blast the reputation of an amiable young Lady, and drive her from the protection of Mr. Hargrave's family.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What! a league with her Servants?

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: And how dare you accuse me of this—Am I to answer for the conduct of my servants?

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: The villainy of your servants is the consequence of those principles with which you have poison'd their minds. Robb'd of their religion, they were left without support—against temptations to which you, Madam, have felt, Philosophy opposes its shield in vain.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: I feel his superiority to my inmost soul—but he shall not see his triumph [aside]—Is it your virtue which prompts you to load me with injuries, to induce Mr. Hargrave to break through every tie of honour—through the most sacred engagements!

sp.speaker: Mr. D.
sp.p: I have just heard these terms, nearly as much prostituted by your servants, who reproach you with not keeping your engagements to them.

sp.speaker: Lady D.
sp.p: Ha! Am I then betrayed?

sp.speaker: Geo.
